DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Miami Lawyer Says He'll Never Be Tried on Drug Charges
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An attorney representing deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega said Sunday there was little chance he would be returned to the United States for trial on drug charges. Noriega ended an intense manhunt Sunday when he drove to the Vatican's mission in Panama City and asked for sanctuary. It remained unclear that night what the Vatican's response would be. ``I'm really quite surprised. I was sure he'd die in Panama,'' said Raymond Takiff, Noriega's attorney in Miami. ``Honest to God, I am really surprised. I'm glad he's alive.'' Takiff said he tried without success to contact Noriega on Sunday, but an ambassador from a third country arranged for them to speak by phone early Christmas morning. Takiff said the papal embassy is so well known as a sanctuary in Panama that he found it hard to believe Noriega could arrive there unobserved. ``Maybe it was a setup, that U.S. troops would look the other way,'' Takiff said. The attorney said he doubted the Vatican would turn Noriega over to the United States. ``The Roman Catholic Church has been sanctuary forever,'' he said. ``An individual who comes to seek sanctuary will be given sanctuary. That goes back to the very roots of the Catholic church.'' Takiff said prosecuting Noriega, who has a long association with the Central Intelligence Agency, would reveal so much sensitive information about U.S. foreign policy that a trial is unlikely. ``I've always said they will never want to try him. I always thought the only option was to kill him,'' Takiff said. ``I never was clever enough to think of sanctuary in the Vatican. In either event, he doesn't get tried.''
